issues.title: Proposal for Workload and Machine Identity Assurance Levels
issues.author: mspinagit
issues.body:
Attached please find proposals for models representing Workload (w) and Machine (m) Identity Assurance Levels modeled after NIST SP 800-63B Person Identity Assurance Levels. These models have direct applicability to Verifier Governance Requirements and may be used to grade a verifier's processes and procedures in an assurance context. 

[Workload Identity Assurance-Proofing for CCC-PR-25-00411-4.docx](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19967201/Workload.Identity.Assurance-Proofing.for.CCC-PR-25-00411-4.docx)
[Machine Identity Assurance-Proofing for CCC-PR_25-00411-3.docx](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/19967200/Machine.Identity.Assurance-Proofing.for.CCC-PR_25-00411-3.docx)

issues.title: Use Cases in the IETF ID seem more like requirements
issues.author: ajfeldma-google
issues.body:
The three items in the [Use Cases](https://github.com/confidential-computing/twi-wimse/blob/main/draft-twi-reference-architecture.md#twi-use-cases) section of the IETF ID seem more like requirements than use cases. They also overlap somewhat with the bullets listed in the Introduction, Gap Analysis, and Core Requirements sections.

IMO, Use Cases should look more like examples or scenarios illustrating how the proposed standard could be put into practice — something that would be good to include and could be valuable in making the proposal more concrete.

comments.author: yogeshbdeshpande
comments.body:
Yes, My intention in the original draft was to use Practical Real World Use Cases of Relevance that will highlight the need and importance of TWI.

Need to re-write this section.

issues.title: [DISCUSS] Documenting `HSM` as an equivalent alternative to in-place key generation
issues.author: TheBankster
issues.body:
> [!NOTE] > > _[EDIT 6/17/2025]_ Reworded to reflect the current state of discussion. The original comment is captured below the `---`. ## Problem statement #### Should TWI-WIMSE I-D (and, by extension, the TWI arch.) document use of HSMs (credential **sharing** concept) as a _level_ option for achieving Trustworthy Workload Identity ❓ ## Considerations 1. For the **smallest** Trusted Computing Base (hence: strongest security guarantees), a Workload needs to be the **sole** entity capable of completing a proof of possession of a Credential. * In practical terms, it would mean the Workload (WL) **generates** its own keys🔑 in-place and has an Identity Provider issue a Credential🏅 bound to them, without ever exposing the secret part outside of the Workload (i.e. [CSR Attestation](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ietf-lamps-csr-attestation/)). 2. Method (1) is **not** attainable for all existing workloads _(looking to migrate their **current** credentials into TWI-compatible systems)_ or when credential secret sharing is explicitly required. TWI wants to address these usages as well. * Solutions for this case (2) require the secret to be **generated**🔢 and **stored**🔐 _externally_ to a Workload and provided to it upon request _(i.e., WL instantiation)_, if (and only if) the **secret release policy**🔎 matches. * Since the key is now cold-stored outside of the WL instance, the storage medium becomes part of the TCB as it _can_ impersonate any workload. * Contemporarily, such centralized secret generation & storage functions are typically served by KMS systems backed by physical Hardware Security Module boxes (often PKCS#11 and FIPS-compliant). * Most HSMs excel at secret protection and performant crypto operations, but are **not** general-purpose TEEs, hence lack the ability to run policy authorization code, instead relying on classic access authorization (i.e. password, pins). Effectively, while the master secret may be well secured inside an HSM (incl. non-exportable), access to it is effectively controlled by a construct analogous to a **bearer token**, making everyone in its possession capable of turning the HSM a "signing oracle". * Specifically, the general-purpose HSM units don't allow to perform a **runtime attestation** before accessing the secret. This includes a "wrapped" key export to another location - a HSM can ensure the key never leaves in a plaintext form, but cannot attest whether the owner of a wrapping key is a properly attested TEE or a simulator. There are notable exceptions here, as there *are* HSM offerings capable of running code, hence theoretically capable of attesting the target. For example, see Thales's [Functionality Modules](https://thalesdocs.com/gphsm/luna/7/docs/network/Content/admin_hsm/fms/fms.htm) or Fortanix's [Secure Business Logic](https://www.fortanix.com/platform/data-security-manager/secure-business-logic). 3. Security drawbacks of secret _sharing_ ((2), above): 1. Expands the TCB to include the storage medium (i.e. HSM) and its policies. Circumvention of the master store's (i.e. "HSM") policies is a BORE attack, allowing to impersonate any Workload using such store. Note this seems **unavoidable** (just a property of secret sharing). 3. Unless the KMS/HSM is able to **attest** the workload on key release, this crosses from a HW-based TEE-land, to a (weaker) policy-based one, changing the typical CC trust model to include an operator inside the TCB (an entity injecting the HSM access credential into the Workload can impersonate it). ## What needs discussion by CCC TWI 1. Moving the this discussion into `TWI Architecture`. _My claim_: WIMSE draft doesn't need the level of detail such as explicit mentions of a concrete solutions (here: HSM), so we can side-step the controversy by keeping it vague and deferring the conversation till later.
> [!TIP] > If we agree, the action item is to prune all HSM mentions from `twi-wimse I-D` and replace with a more high-level statement to the effect of `TWI means to also support secret sharing concept`. 2. Define security guarantee levels TWI can offer and grade the solutions by them. For example: 1. 🥇 **Level1** (best) _[recommended for greenfield deployments]_: Have workloads self-generate their secrets - no key sharing. * If cold storage of credentials is required (cannot be derived ad hoc), it's the Workload who decides how to pass their secrets on to the storage (likely encrypted, i.e. using a HW sealing mechanism, if available platform-side). 3. 🥈 **Level2** have the KMS system (sharing keys) capable of remotely attesting a Workload before sharing a key with them * Note that while this is n/a for a regular PKCS#11-only HSM, it can be done in one of the units capable of running policy code (some examples listed above), or the KMS may itself be a TEE (a TWI Workload), possibly even using Threshold Cryptography and running Byzantine Fault-Tolerant state machine replication. 3. 🥉 **Level3** (worst): have the KMS use **bearer** credentials (i.e. a client TLS certificate + HSM partition password) to authorize key use/export. Such credentials are injected into the Workload by a **hosting platform** (or its user operator). * The HSM credentials would should only be disbursed upon a successful Workload attestation by the platform, yet it still requires to include this mechanism inside the TCB (which now spans: Workload, HSM, Platform), as the Platform can impersonate the Workload when talking to a HSM. ----
Original wording of this issue (👆click to expand) The `HSM` piece is a little fuzzy, esp. as I'm not aware of any HSM offering capable of runtime attestation of a TEE/enclave (which would be required for it to issue any kind of key). On the other hand, if the attestation was to be unidirectional only (TWI attests 'its' crypto provider before asking for key), then: - If the HSM is 'just' a stateless key **generator**, it feels like we can just wrap it under "TEE generates the key umbrella", w/o over defining. - If the HSM has state (and this is a key **sharing** concept), we have introduced new attack surface (non-CC, it suffices to break the HSM auth token). _Originally posted by @mbronk-intc in https://github.com/confidential-computing/twi-wimse/pull/12#discussion_r2108890703_

issues.title: Workload Identifier meaning - discuss at more length
issues.author: TheBankster
issues.body:
Design Considerations
Should the ID be globally unique or partitioned by workload type?

Should it encode temporal data (e.g., epoch-based) or be strictly incrementing?

Will IDs ever need to be re-used or recycled?

Best practice usually involves combining a timestamp component (for ordering) with a counter or unique suffix (for deduplication). Lets discuss

_Originally posted by @Mainsailthewolfe in https://github.com/confidential-computing/twi-wimse/pull/14#discussion_r2137493317_

issues.title: Discuss the precise definition of Lineage and then update the Charter with it
issues.author: TheBankster
issues.body:
> ...and also... this, as stated, is easily misunderstood to mean something other than what we want it to mean. For instance, the name of an issuer bound to the credential is a "linkage" between that credential and the issuer, but it says nothing about provenance. Provenance is something specific to the credential in question that can help identify which decisions led to the issuance of the credential. Let's discuss.

Let’s be careful not to conflate linkage with provenance. The presence of an issuer name is a linkage—but provenance captures the credential’s path and intent, including issuance context and decision lineage.

The current language risks conflating linkage (e.g., “issuer name in a credential”) with provenance (the broader context and history of how and why the credential was created). This confusion can lead to incorrect assumptions about trust, authenticity, and responsibility.

_Originally posted by @Mainsailthewolfe in https://github.com/confidential-computing/twi-wimse/pull/14#discussion_r2137508007_

issues.title: We might want to add "lack of certainty about the composition of the workload" which captures both weak attestation and lack of provenance information
issues.author: TheBankster
issues.body:
We might want to add "lack of certainty about the composition of the workload" which captures both weak attestation and lack of provenance information

_Originally posted by @TheBankster in https://github.com/confidential-computing/twi-wimse/pull/14#discussion_r2123670821_

comments.body: Should we have "provenance ID" or leave it to be more general? If just an ID, like "jti", how can RP know where the breadcrumb leads? Go interrogate the credential issuer?
For each term, define it here, or point to where it is defined? Someone with IETF knowledge should chime in.
Should we reiterate use cases and reference the Requirements document? My vote yes.
issuing, not provisioning. Provisioning is the process of obtaining a credential from an issuer, which is done by the workload or the workload owner.
This is hardly a diversion, more of an additional property that CC guarantees.

This will be perceived as far too metadata added to the workload, will probably generate pushback. A provenance ID is much smaller and can lead to all of the below. Perhaps instead have a section that explains all the things that provenance delivers.

Terms used in the document should be defined here unless the definition is so extensive it needs an external reference. Then a brief description is placed here and a normative reference is added later in the document.

pulls.title: Added the three core use cases
pulls.author: TheBankster
pulls.body:
Added the three requirements that make an identity "trustworthy"
As discussed in today's TWI SIG meeting these are the core requirements we'd like to meet.
Also added a couple of proposed sections for the Reference Architecture.

pulls.title: Updates and restructuring of document
pulls.author: dpquigl
pulls.body:
This commit introduces the following changes:

	1. Addition of TWI charter and requirements document in the informative reference section
	2. Rewrite of the abstract
	3. Addition of introductary text from TWI SIG Charter
	4. Removal of the glossary section merging it with Conventions and Definitions
	5. Inlining of various definitions from the TWISIG Charter
	6. Updating references to the various TWI SIG documents as actual references instead of URLs
	7. Introduced gap analysis section using content from the TWI SIG WIMSE Gap analysis document
	8. Introduced a confidential compute integration section using contents from the TWI SIG WIMSE gap analysis document.
	9. Removed reference architecture section as that should be a separate document. This document is to outline existing issues and what the requirements are that need to be met that are not currently being met.

pulls.title: [chore] Hyperlinks update after repo rename to `twi-wimse`
pulls.author: mbronk-intc
pulls.body: Housekeeping: Updates to README and LICENSE files to reflect the new GH repository name (`twi`->`twi-wimse`)

pulls.title: Added a devcontainer for quick local preview of HTML I-D
pulls.author: mbronk-intc
pulls.body:
## Adds support of [Dev Containers](https://containers.dev/) for easier local authoring. 
#### Purely OPTIONAL❕

When opened up in a compatible IDE _(i.e. VSCode, w/ [`Dev Containers` extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode-remote.remote-containers))_ or [GH Codespace](https://github.com/codespaces/new?repo=confidential-computing/twi-wimse&ref=main), will open up a dev container pre-set up with the Internet Draft toolchain.
Note 1st launch may take a considerable while!

## Features supported
* All of the [goodness](https://github.com/martinthomson/i-d-template/blob/main/doc/FEATURES.md) brought by [martinthomson's I-D-Template](https://github.com/martinthomson/i-d-template) should 🤞  be available via `make` CLI commands
* By default, a [`kdwatch`](https://github.com/cabo/kdwatch)-based live renderer launches on startup and displays live preview of the document at [`http://localhost:3000`](http://127.0.0.1:3000/). 
    * Further information [here](https://authors.ietf.org/drafting-in-markdown)

pulls.title: Added a section on Credential Provenance (aside Workload Provenance)
pulls.author: mbronk-intc
pulls.body:
Added a separate section on `Credential Provenance` to distinguish:
- the provenance of the workload (bound to its lifecycle, and its own properties - possibly externally-sourced)
- the provenance of the credential itself (bound to lifespan of the credential, likely internally-sourced)

Hinging on the assumption of: `workload identity` and `workload credential` being `1:N` mapped.

### likely needs more discussion!

comments.body:
### Wordsmithing: this is a separate suggestion, proposing a little more consensual tone. 
While there **are** divergences and trust model incompatibilities indeed, I believe our end-goal is to extend, not to diverge... hence I'd propose to use a little softer wording to keep readers engaged (and let them uncover the incompatibilities **themselves**, vs. **us** claiming `X is divergent`).
Our goal right now is to highlight Divergence, for now to gain traction in WIMSE.

Gotcha! This was just to stimulate a conversation on which phraseology is more likely to give us the most bang for the buck. :) 
I trust your judgement with the IETF community though, so if you say it is A-OK to enumerate divergencies, I'll happily revert this change as it is indeed more crisp as-is.

pulls.title: Editorial: fixed glossary rendering to HTML
pulls.author: mbronk-intc

pulls.title: Expanded discussion of Provenance, rearranged sections
pulls.author: TheBankster

comments.body: Capitalizing terms that are not introduced yet in the abstract is not a huge problem, but is typically started after the terminology section. I am not objecting. At this point the "issue is basically "immaterial".
scale of uplift and immature tooling might require a representative reference at this early point of the document

Using the named word "identities" is often avoided (because it attracts trouble sometimes. I assume that referencing wimse reduces that issue, also including our scoped definition in the TWI I-D helps.
use of "this". Repetition of the problem statement is fine.
Maybe avoid "will" in the phrasing. Maybe "require dedicated alignment to fit within"

```suggestion
This Section presents a gap analysis between TWIs and the current WIMSE architecture (link). The gap analysis is currently an ongoing activity as part of the collaboration of the Confidential Computing Consortium and the WIMSE WG to identify and define extensions required to address trustworthiness levels as defined by the Confidential Computing environments.
```

Maybe consider:
1. Generation, which includes Collection
2. Conveyance
3. Appraisal, which fuels Utilization

```suggestion
For the Credential exchange patterns defined in the WIMSE Credential Exchange draft, Confidential Computing can provide a secure TEE in which the exchange logic runs. This ensures that the process of exchanging or re-provisioning credentials is protected against tampering and eavesdropping.
```

```suggestion
For Use Case 1, the Workload MUST run in an isolated, remotely attested TEE. Therefore, the process of obtaining the Credentials MUST involve a Verifier service in addition to the Identity Provider service.
```

Are the `trustworthiness levels as defined by the Confidential Computing environments` defined somewhere already or do we need to coin them here (love the idea, BTW).
This may be a good reference point: https://slsa.dev/spec/draft/attested-build-env-levels

Nitpicking: This section is introduced as "extensions to WIMSE", which the heading (`Protection of Credentials at runtime, key management in dynamic environments`) matches as well.
The sub-bullets read more like a gap/problem statement, though. IMHO it would flow better if either:
  1. The section was about "**gaps**", and the heading renamed to something like
      > "**Lack of** strong protection of Credentials at runtime, **problematic** key management in dynamic environments"
    
     -or-

  2. Keep this as `extensions to WIMSE` but then have sub-bullets pre-introduced with a **qualifier**. I.e. 
```markdown
- Protection of Credentials at runtime, key management in dynamic environments:
    **Problem statement:**
      - Risk that credentials in memory could be exposed if a workload’s execution environment is compromised.
      - The current solutions rely on traditional key management practices which may not withstand common runtime attacks.
      - Runtime can still be compromised, even if keys are securely managed, a compromised runtime can still leak.
        Similarly, a secure runtime is less effective if key management is weak. 

  **Proposed extension:**
     - Have the credentials protected at runtime and isolated from workload's runtime environment (by using a Trusted Execution Environment).
     - Integrate both robust key lifecycle management and continuous runtime attestation for better security.
```

```suggestion
   - Confidential Computing seeks to isolate Workload instances from both the hosting environments and peer Workloads.
   - WIMSE Architecture is built on a foundational assumption that the hosting environment is fully trusted, whereas - under Confidential Computing - Remote Attestation is used to ascertain the identity of the Workload, irrespective of the hosting environment.
   - Further, some Confidential Computing scenarios seek to combine claims about the Workload instance with claims, such as physical location, of the hosting environment, and different (yet collaborating) attestation mechanisms must be employed to achieve that.
```

1. We likely need a citation for ` foundational assumption that the hosting environment is fully trusted`
2. Let's stick to **1-sentence per line** for an easier review

> Confidential Computing employs a Verifier service to perform remote attestation,

Perhaps better to refer to a RATS Verifier here? I.e. not sure if we need to call it a 'service' - keeping it as a role is more flexible.
A little open-ended... Perhaps add a sentence on what is CC proposing in this area (i.e. no Bearer tokens, workload generating its own keys)

To crisp it up (and distinguish from just any binding), we may consider coining a term `strong binding` (or similar) and use here:
```suggestion
2. Any credential representing a Workload Identity is strongly bound to that Workload instance
```
+a add a term definition in the terminology sect.

Consider a 4th
```
4. A Workload Credential issuance can be audited (optionally, by an external entity) for the entirety of its lifecycle (including a retroactive analysis).
```

The `HSM` piece is a little fuzzy, esp. as I'm not aware of any HSM offering capable of runtime attestation of a TEE/enclave (which would be required for it to issue any kind of key).

On the other hand, if the attestation was to be unidirectional only (TWI attests 'its' crypto provider before asking for key), then:
  - If the HSM is 'just' a stateless key **generator**, it feels like we can just wrap it under "TEE generates the key <somehow> umbrella", w/o over defining.
  - If the HSM has state (and this is a key **sharing** concept), we have introduced new attack surface (non-CC, it suffices to break the HSM auth token).

+1
I'd also suggest decoupling 'workload creation' from 'credential creation'
I am going to opt for consistency of capitalization of certain words throughout the document. We can always change that later.

> scale of uplift and immature tooling might require a representative reference at this early point of the document

I have removed that wording as it is not needed for the draft

> Using the named word "identities" is often avoided (because it attracts trouble sometimes. I assume that referencing wimse reduces that issue, also including our scoped definition in the TWI I-D helps.

What are you proposing we change in response to this comment? I'm not clear.

> use of "this". Repetition of the problem statement is fine.

What do you mean by 'use of "this"'?

> Maybe avoid "will" in the phrasing. Maybe "require dedicated alignment to fit within"

I just said (lowercase) "must" to make this requirement explicit.
I don't believe the CCC defines "trustworthiness levels".

> 

The proposed wording does not clarify things (for me at least) and contains a couple of typos. I kept some of it in my reworded suggestion.

```suggestion
The Confidential Computing Consortium defines Confidential Computing as "protection of data in use by performing computation in a hardware-based, attested Trusted Execution Environment (TEE)". Confidential Computing can address the existing shortcomings in a way that is compatible with the emerging Workload Identity solution ecosystem and can evolve in alignment with the expectations of the owners and operators of Confidential Computing Workloads. These efforts will build on the concept of _Trustworthy Workload Identity_ (TWI) defined further below. Data-in-use protection of Workloads that have such Identities will be a critical downstream effect.
```
I just defined the acronym at the first use

```suggestion
Strengthening the initial bootstrapping process. A TEE can provide hardware-based attestation that a workload is running in a secure, isolated environment. This attestation could be used as an additional factor during Credential provisioning, ensuring that only Workloads running in a TEE and meeting Verifier policies, receive valid Credentials. (TODO: revisit: might be a bit of a stretch/ too much - it basically would be an extension of the bootstrapping projects described in WIMSE {{-WIMSE}}).
```

```suggestion
This Internet-Draft covers a gap analysis performed by the Confidential Computing Consortium on WIMSE identifying areas where the current WIMSE Architecture should be extended to accommodate Workloads running in Confidential Computing environments. It outlines high-level requirements for these extensions and describes a series of use cases.
```
Note: We need to describe the series of use cases, properly, as promised!
We need to clarify which tokens are we talking about. This is the first time we have used the term tokens without setting any context!

```suggestion
Incorporating confidential computing within the workload’s execution environment can lower the risk of runtime attacks (such as memory scraping or side-channel attacks) that can expose critical identity or authentication tokens. For example, the confidential computing environment can be used to securely generate and verify proofs of possession that are important within the WIMSE authentication protocol.
```
* Here I was seeking Practical Real World Use Cases: That Demonstrates the Value of this Work Item.

I think the existing wording is fine. If you look at Azure, a workload attests with MAS (Microsoft Attestation Service) and then gets a key out of HSM. HSM is not "under the TEE umbrella" in that case, as any entity that matches the HSM's key release policy can get that key as well.
Let's discuss this in the next TWI meeting. I struggle with this paragraph even as written (it was not written by me).
This I believe is captured by #3. This paragraph references the already established definition of TWI, but we can make changes to #3 including clarifying that it also includes retroactive auditing.
I updated the text in response to this suggestion.
Updated wording to address this comment. Stopped short of proposed changes as that happens later in the document.
Should we say "credential replay" here?
Rather than say "required security guarantees", let's say "meeting Verifier policies"?

```suggestion
- Credential Replay and Misuse in Cross-domain Scenarios:
```
See issue #13

```suggestion
3. A Workload Credential can be traced back to the Workload’s Provenance, either at runtime or for a later audit
```

reviews.author: henkbirkholz
reviews.body: Resolved issues in regular call. :ship: it

pulls.title: Some Editorial Refurbishment
pulls.author: henkbirkholz
pulls.body:
Proposing:

* some changes to markdown syntax
* reshaping the terminology section style
* changes to the TOC structure
* minor editorial phrasing changes

comments.body: We might want to add "lack of certainty about the composition of the workload" which captures both weak attestation and lack of provenance information
"a trusted entity" implies only one, but there's a combination of entities at play here. Let's discuss?
This is not part of credential usage so not in scope for WIMSE.

```suggestion
Until recently, there were few scenarios requiring data-in-use protections. This is starting to change. Regulatory bodies worldwide are increasingly requiring data-in-use protection and privacy-enhancing technologies. Outside of regulatory requirements, companies are exploring:
```

```suggestion
This document illustrates a gap analysis that is the output of the Confidential Computing Consortium identifying areas in the IETF WIMSE WG work where the current WIMSE architecture should be amended to accommodate workloads running in Confidential Computing environments. This document outlines high-level requirements for the these extensions and describes a series of use cases.
```

```suggestion
* Addressing the risks of computing in public clouds and high-risk locations
```

```suggestion
Until recently, there were few scenarios requiring data-in-use protection. This is starting to change. Regulatory bodies worldwide are increasingly requiring data-in-use protection and privacy-enhancing technologies. Outside of regulatory requirements, companies are exploring:
```

```suggestion
Correspondingly, there is an increased push to harmonize management and governance of human and non-human identities.
Modern workloads may operate on their own behalf with their own credentials, or as agents on behalf of other entities with delegated credentials.
Entities interested in strong assurances around the security of their deployed workloads, for regulatory, contractual or peace of mind reasons, are starting to face large and challenging tasks of upgrading their existing computing system infrastructure to meet these requirements.
```

```suggestion
3. Lack of verifiable composition of the workload, and inability to associate a credential with a set of decisions leading up to its issuance
```

```suggestion
In the immediate term, effective Confidential Computing faces a significant challenge: the scale of uplift and immature tooling are both clear barriers.
Longer term, however, Confidential Computing provides a vital improvement due to its unique features (i.e., verifiable composition, strong workload isolation) and broad availability (i.e., support by all major hardware vendors).
Multiple emerging regulations will mean that customers will be looking to these features and capabilities to satisfy them.
```

```suggestion
Confidential Computing-assisted mechanisms have to align with the emerging Workload Identity solution ecosystem. Correspondingly, the evolution of the Workload Identity ecosystem should remain in alignment with the expectations of the owners and operators of Confidential Computing workloads.
To address this set of requirements, this document defines and elaborates on the concept of `Trustworthy Workload Identity` (TWI) in the following Sections.
Data-in-use protection of workloads supporting TWI results in critical downstream effects.
```

```suggestion
Until recently, there were few scenarios requiring data-in-use protection. This is starting to change. Regulatory bodies worldwide are increasingly requiring data-in-use protection and privacy enhancing technologies. Outside of regulatory requirements, companies are exploring:
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
: The definition of Workload in this document restricts the definition of the term Workload as defined by {{-WIMSE}} to composition of code and configuration of a (WIMSE-defined) Workload that runs in a Trusted Execution Environment and is subject to Remote Attestation.
```

...and also... this, as stated, is easily misunderstood to mean something other than what we want it to mean. For instance, the name of an issuer bound to the credential is a "linkage" between that credential and the issuer, but it says nothing about provenance. Provenance is something specific to the credential in question that can help identify which decisions led to the issuance of the credential. Let's discuss.
The gaps are not just about risks. Lack of provenance is a gap, but not a "risk" per se.

```suggestion
With TEEs, a workload’s private keys and sensitive cryptographic operations (such as signing or validating tokens) can be isolated from the hosting environment, reducing the risk of key leakage even if the surrounding system is compromised. (For instance, the WIMSE token—be it a JWT or an X.509 certificate—can be generated and signed within a TEE, ensuring that the proof-of-possession mechanism remains intact.)
```

```suggestion
Strengthening the initial bootstrapping process. A TEE can provide hardware-based attestation that a workload is running in a secure, isolated environment. This attestation could be used as an additional factor during credential provisioning, ensuring that only workloads running in a TEE and matching the credential issuer's attestation policies receive valid credentials.
```

```suggestion
For the credential exchange patterns defined in the WIMSE Credential Exchange draft, Confidential Computing can provide a Trusted Execution Environment in which the exchange logic runs. This ensures that the process of exchanging or re-provisioning credentials is protected against tampering and eavesdropping.
```

```suggestion
Executing the Workload inside a Trusted Execution Environment can lower the risk that runtime attacks (such as memory scraping or side-channel attacks) can expose critical identity or authentication tokens. For example, a Trusted Execution Environment can be used to securely generate and verify proofs of possession that are important within the WIMSE authentication protocol.
```
Check numbering. "3" is wrong here.
Going from Use Case 1 to Use Case 3. Where's 2?

A Workload Identifier is a unique reference assigned to a job, process, service instance, or workload unit within a system. In the below section we are defining a workload identifier as a workload identifier. Lets discuss

Additionally we should also consider the fact that a continuous Workload Identifier is preferred to a random workload identifier. This will allow the ability to maintain provenance across the workload lifecycle in a sequential manner.  Lets discuss

Design Considerations
Should the ID be globally unique or partitioned by workload type?

Should it encode temporal data (e.g., epoch-based) or be strictly incrementing?

Will IDs ever need to be re-used or recycled?

Best practice usually involves combining a timestamp component (for ordering) with a counter or unique suffix (for deduplication). Lets discuss

> "a trusted entity" implies only one, but there's a combination of entities at play here. Let's discuss?

Referring to ‘a trusted entity’ suggests singularity, which misrepresents our architecture. We should clarify that trust may be derived from a composite of entities, not just one, especially in distributed or federated issuance models

> ...and also... this, as stated, is easily misunderstood to mean something other than what we want it to mean. For instance, the name of an issuer bound to the credential is a "linkage" between that credential and the issuer, but it says nothing about provenance. Provenance is something specific to the credential in question that can help identify which decisions led to the issuance of the credential. Let's discuss.

Let’s be careful not to conflate linkage with provenance. The presence of an issuer name is a linkage—but provenance captures the credential’s path and intent, including issuance context and decision lineage.

The current language risks conflating linkage (e.g., “issuer name in a credential”) with provenance (the broader context and history of how and why the credential was created). This confusion can lead to incorrect assumptions about trust, authenticity, and responsibility.
Can the "gap" turn into or become a "risk" if not addressed in this  context?

```suggestion
This document illustrates a gap analysis that is the output of the Confidential Computing Consortium identifying areas in the IETF WIMSE WG work where the current WIMSE architecture should be extended to accommodate workloads running in Confidential Computing environments. This document outlines high-level requirements for the these extensions and describes a series of use cases.
```
As CC is gaining popularity now, shall we delete line 76..? The reason been, it water down a bit our efforts for a need for CC?

```suggestion
The following risks were identified by a gap analysis of the current WIMSE architecture {{-WIMSE}} performed by the Confidential Computing Consortium. The gap analysis provides a basis for identify extensions necessary to meet the level of trustworthiness required by confidential computing environments:
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
Confidential Computing can close these architectural gaps due to its unique features (i.e., verifiable composition, strong workload isolation) and broad availability (i.e., support by all major hardware vendors).
```

```suggestion
: {{-WIMSE}} defines 'Workload' as "an instance of software executing for a specific purpose. Here we restrict that definition to the portion of the software instance and its configuration that is subject to Remote Attestation.
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
: is a stable construct around which Relying Parties can form long-lived Workload authorization policies.
```
Discussed in the meeting and closed.

```suggestion
: the definition of Workload Identity is identical to the definition of the same term by {{-WIMSE}}: "a combination of three basic building blocks: trust domain, Workload Identifier and identity credentials.
```

```suggestion
The following shortcomings were identified by performing a gap analysis of the current WIMSE architecture {{-WIMSE}} against the requirements underlying Trustworthy Workload Identity (TWI). The gap analysis provides a basis for identifying extensions necessary to meet the level of trustworthiness required by Confidential Computing environments.
```

```suggestion
* Protection of Credentials at runtime and insufficient Runtime Attestation:
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
  * Confidential Computing does not trust its hosting environment and relies on each Workload attesting itself.
```

```suggestion
* Token replay and misuse:
```

```suggestion
  * Token binding, even if used, is not sufficient unless the secrets underpinning the workload's credentials are protected from leakage.
```
Discuss provenance in the gap analysis

```suggestion
: a stable construct around which Relying Parties can form long-lived Workload authorization policies.
```
actual numbers in an numbered list is ignored by kramdown, but yes - it's off
It's in new line 165 and in old line 131
Agree (:+1), but it might have relevance in the provenance context

reviews.author: yogeshbdeshpande
reviews.body: LGTM, left one minor comment, but in general looks good to me!

comments.body:
"_Confidential Computing does not trust its hosting environment_" may be misleading as the hardware could also colloquially be thought of as a part of hosting environment.
Try:
```suggestion
  * Confidential Computing (CC) relies on each Workload attesting _itself_ to a _hardware_ Root of Trust (HW RoT). CC is explicitly considering the hosting environment configuration and firmware/software (i.e. virtualization stack controlled by the environment provider) as _untrusted_.
```

reviews.author: mbronk-intc
reviews.body:
LGTM. 
Added +suggestion, but regardless of whether we apply it, I vote to merge this PR and do a proper 2nd sweep of the doc afterwards (i.e., deduplicate).
